title: [Coursera - Stanford] Algorithms: Design and Analysis Part 2
description:
[Coursera | Stanford University] Algorithms: Design and Analysis, Part 2 [2014]
===============================================================================

Released Year: 2014
Language: English
Publisher: Coursera / Stanford University
Author: Tim Roughgarden

Video: H263 (MP4), 960x540, 30fps
Audio: mp4a, 44100 Hz, stereo 

Description
=============

	In this course you will learn several fundamental principles of advanced algorithm design. You'll learn the greedy algorithm design paradigm, with applications to computing good network backbones (i.e., spanning trees) and good codes for data compression. You'll learn the tricky yet widely applicable dynamic programming algorithm design paradigm, with applications to routing in the Internet and sequencing genome fragments. YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll learn what NP-completeness and the famous Ã¢â‚¬Å“P vs. NPÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ problem mean for the algorithm designer. Finally, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll study several strategies for dealing with hard (i.e., NP-complete problems), including the design and analysis of heuristics. Learn how shortest-path algorithms from the 1950s (i.e., pre-ARPANET!) govern the way that your Internet traffic gets routed today; why efficient algorithms are fundamental to modern genomics; and how to make a million bucks in prize money by Ã¢â‚¬Å“justÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ solving a math problem!

Course Syllabus
---------------

Weeks 1 and 2: The greedy algorithm design paradigm. Applications to optimal caching and scheduling. Minimum spanning trees and applications to clustering. The union-find data structure. Optimal data compression.
Weeks 3 and 4: The dynamic programming design paradigm. Applications to the knapsack problem, sequence alignment, shortest-path routing, and optimal search trees.
Weeks 5 and 6: Intractable problems and what to do about them. NP-completeness and the P vs. NP question. Solvable special cases. Heuristics with provable performance guarantees. Local search. Exponential-time algorithms that beat brute-force search
